DOC.HEAD: Cold Snap Reaches New Depths
By The Associated Press
DOC.TEXT: Plenty of evidence of winter was available today on the first full day of the season, with wind chill readings down to 80 degrees below zero and up to 1{ feet of snow in the nation's Northern regions. Meanwhile, Miami reported a record high of 81 degrees Thursday, tying a 1948 record for the date. Brutally cold, windy conditions were reported across much of the Central and Northeastern United States. On Thursday, strong northerly winds kept temperatures dropping right through the morning and afternoon hours. Temperatures remained below freezing all day from the Texas plains to the northern half of the Atlantic Coast. Temperatures remained below zero all day across the upper half of the Mississippi Valley, the northern Plains and much of the central Plains. In north-central Montana, the mercury hovered close to 40 degrees below zero all day at Havre. A total of 40 cities reported new record lows Thursday, including 13 cities in Iowa. The cold created shortages of heating oil in some Northeastern depots, and led the Tennessee Valley Authority to ask its customers to reduce their morning electrical use. Schools were closed in many Central and Northern states. More records were expected to be broken today and Saturday. Wind chill readings of 70 to 80 degrees below zero were forecast for early today in the north-central states and down to 50 degrees below in the Northeast. Squalls were producing heavy snow over parts of the Great Lakes, with up to 16 inches in northern Indiana, and smaller amounts in Ohio and Pennsylvania. A mixture of snow, sleet and freezing rain was forecast for southern Texas, with a snow advisory in effect for the panhandle and Texas plains. A gale warning was posted along the western Gulf late Thursday. Temperatures were above 50 degrees Thursday in extreme southern Texas, Florida and parts of Georgia and South Carolina. The high for the nation Thursday was 82 degrees at Key West, Fla. Sunny skies and mild temperatures prevailed west of the Rockies, with highs mostly in the 40s and 50s, and in the 60s and 70s in Southern California and southern Arizona.
